Hammond Maxwell.Action: Fancies himself decent and moral, a good and kind master to his slaves
Is not mentioned or does not take any observable action or make statements in the excerpt.
Claims he never altered horses or slaves on the plantation and expresses some restrained sympathy for the bucks running scared.
Discusses selling Cicero, a slave, and smiles pleased at the high price, showing business-like detachment.
Confidently negotiates the sale price of Cicero, securing a higher price than the initial offer.
Shows clear knowledge of the slaves' abilities and behavior, accurately identifying Cicero as a prime worker and a runner.
Expresses indignation about altering slaves or horses, which reflects a personal or familial principle rather than practical ineptitude.
Greets his father with a kiss, shows gentleness and shyness.
Politely shakes hands with Brownlee and expresses being 'right charmed' by his company.
Acknowledges Redfield as the best veterinary anywhere nearby, showing respect for expertise.
Appears startled, disconcerted, and confused by Redfield's advice about pleasuring Big Pearl, suggesting some discomfort or uncertainty in handling the situation.
States that it is a master's duty to pleasure the wenches the first time, reflecting a confident assertion of his role despite internal unease.
Smiles and engages with Agamemnon's ironic response, oblivious to it
Rubs his father's hand fondly despite his own pain
Expresses cynical, dismissive views about the souls and religion of enslaved people
Responds confidently to Agamemnon's attitude, smiling and showing satisfaction with his own views.
Expresses prejudiced and simplistic views about religion and souls in a dismissive manner, ignoring possible deeper understanding or sensitivity.
Manages physical pain from rheumatism while still carrying out simple tasks like pouring milk and interacting with others.
Kisses his father tenderly before leaving despite his limp
Calmly informs Lucrezia to prepare Big Pearl, showing responsibility and communication
Informs others decisively that he is going and makes immediate arrangements (telling Lucrezia to prepare Big Pearl).
Kisses his father affectionately and leaves limping, showing both emotional awareness and physical limitation.
Orders Meg away, signaling control over the black community while they watch him with apprehension
Hesitates and seems unsure before approaching Big Pearl silently
Questions Big Pearl about her feelings, waits for an answer, appears hesitant and unsure before approaching her.
Believes Big Pearl's lie about being joyful and nods with satisfaction, despite her underlying fear.
Seemingly hesitant and unsure, limping over silently without making direct eye contact; waits for a response from Big Pearl before proceeding cautiously.
Successfully deceives Big Pearl by believing her fabricated response, indicating some level of perceptiveness or manipulation.
Snatches paper from Agamemnon, mocks him by saying 'You kin read! Ant write! Who learned you, Mem?!'
Grabs Agamemnon by the arm and shoves him roughly toward the door
Realizes Agamemnon is tongue-tied and looks to Cicero for answers
Tells Maxwell he needs to check Mem's room out of concern
Acknowledges Mem can read, indicating some awareness
Says 'No, Papa... no. I'll jest whup nin.' in response to Maxwell's brutality
Nods but doesn't look happy about the brutal punishment Maxwell orders
Asks Dite if she wants to be in bed, then gently tells her to warm the sheets
Acknowledges Mem can read, showing awareness of unexpected literacy.
Reluctantly agrees to physical punishment as a disciplinary method, showing obedience but lack of enthusiasm or assertiveness.
Follows Maxwell’s detailed instructions on punishment procedure, demonstrating ability to carry out orders precisely.
Does not challenge Maxwell’s harsh and cruel views or orders, passive acceptance of unethical orders.
Relents to Dite about pregnancy, but insists selling the child is 'for your own good.'
Prays sincerely and includes blessings for many people, including slaves on the plantation.
Tells Agamemnon there's no use praying to God for him, implying tough love.
Says to slaves 'you behave like good bucks' and mildly reprimands Cicero for preaching trouble; frowns and shakes head with resigned disapproval
Watches Brownlee tie up slaves and shows no visible empathy toward the grief-stricken slaves or black women who cling to them
Shows calm control and attempts to maintain order among slaves by instructing them to behave and cautiously questioning Cicero about stirring trouble.
Displays resigned disapproval but does not intervene effectively to prevent potential trouble or cruelty witnessed (indifference to Brownlee's harsh treatment).
Shows concern about the treatment of Alph, a sick boy, by physically engaging with him to provide relief.
Scowls and expresses discomfort when his father suggests he needs a white lady to produce a proper heir, revealing discomfort or resistance to his father's racist views.
Is astonished to see a stranger beating Agamemnon and reacts with rage, indicating some protective feelings.
Suggests looking at Cousin Blanche to find a suitable white lady, showing some consideration and openness.
Displays skepticism about kissing women, suggesting a certain emotional distance or discomfort with intimacy.
Comments resignedly that one cannot have more wenches if married, showing acceptance of limitations but no empathy or affection.
Questions advice and displays skepticism about kissing practices and keeping 'wenches' while married, showing some awareness of social rules but uncertain application.
Takes initiative to follow advice to visit Cousin Blanche to assess suitability, indicating willingness to act and gather information.
Greets Wallace warmly and introduces his cousin politely.
Expresses disappointment about the dead Mandingo buck but continues the conversation calmly.
Discusses borrowing a Mandingo slave for breeding and fighting purposes without indication of empathy.
Shares a moment of mutual disgust at cruelty with Ellen; expresses his own disgust at Charles' actions.
Seeks and accepts honest sympathy from Ellen about his leg injury, appreciating her genuine concern.
Acts suspiciously and questions Ellen's gaze with suspicion.
Calmly encourages Ellen to meet his gaze, demonstrating patience and gentle insistence, showing ability to communicate and assert himself effectively.
Feels puzzled and surprised by Ellen's tears, revealing a lack of understanding of her emotional state and cultural context.
Acts on impulse by kissing Ellen on the cheek, a departure from his usual behavior, which startles him.
Offers to pay more money than the German woman asks to prevent her from taking an enslaved man from a poor widow, showing decisiveness and a protective attitude.
Claps Brownlee on the back exuberantly and expresses pride in acquiring a 'fightin' nigger', indicating confidence and perhaps over-enthusiasm.
Does not seem to acknowledge the wary, scrutinizing glance from Mede and gazes happily at him, potentially missing or underestimating Mede's wariness.
Sits quietly in an elegant parlor, appears flustered when addressed but does not respond effectively when interrupted.
Is astutely aware enough to notice and respond to the social setting, though somewhat passive and overshadowed by others like Charles.
Appears terribly embarrassed and unsure how to respond in a tense social situation after Charles humiliates Blanche and him publicly.
Attempts to assert himself by verbally warning Charles and threatening physical violence, showing some confidence but poor control.
Leaps toward Charles with fist raised in anger
Pursues Blanche on the veranda, catches her by the arm
Expresses apology and embarrassment after Blanche’s teasing
Included by Dick in his prayer asking for blessings upon Hammond's slaves
Watches Blanche tenderly and lovingly, shares intimate moments confidently with her.
Expresses uncertainty about how to proceed with Blanche, admitting he doesn't quite know what to do next.
Emerges from the hotel room looking stricken and haggard, gazing blankly at the city, suggesting emotional or mental overwhelm.
Coldly accuses Blanche of infidelity, shows suspicion, calls her disgusting, and leaves slamming the door while she cries.
Confronts Blanche about her past and expresses jealousy and suspicion in a cold, direct manner.
Reacts emotionally by recoiling from Blanche's touch and leaving the room slamming the door.
Sits dazzled and agape in the flamboyant bordello setting, accepting champagne from Madame Caroline who is effusively charming.
Reacts passively as Brownlee jokes about his father's womanizing and slaps him heartily on the back.
Looks around at the women greedily, showing interest in their company.
Allows a blonde girl to sit on the arm of the divan and run her fingers across his face without objection.
Sits dazzled and agape in the flamboyant setting, looking around greedily at the women, spilling his drink when told about his father's unfaithfulness.
Rejects the persistent advances of the blonde woman despite pressure and awkwardness, maintaining loyalty to his bride.
Uses an awkward excuse ('I'm on my honeymoon') to avoid temptation instead of a more firm or confident refusal.
Appears shaken and wretched, showing emotional disturbance that affects his confidence.
Appears on the balcony and commands Mede and Babouin to stop their violent fight.
Appears on a balcony and orders Mede and Babouin to stop fighting.
Watched the fight fascinated, showed sincere pride and encouragement to Mede after his victory.
Refused to sell Mede despite a higher financial offer, indicating strong confidence and decisiveness in his value judgment.
Whips the horses fiercely and spurs the surrey forward
Orders a servant brusquely to get horses water
Describes Cicero as a troublemaker
Exchanges uneasy glance with Blanche, then walks to house entrance and converses with Wallace

Whips the horses fiercely and drives the surrey forward, takes initiative by stopping the horses to give them water, commands Mede to follow his orders, indicates awareness of a troublesome person (Cicero).
Appears uneasy when Blanche questions the stop, shows some uncertainty in front of others.
Buys Ellen, a slave, and takes charge of her transport by instructing the driver and controlling the situation confidently.
Feigns nonchalance when climbing into the surrey, indicating a controlled and skillful demeanor.
Does not appear hesitant or uncertain in his actions related to acquiring and managing Ellen.
Introduces Blanche confidently to Maxwell as his wife and acts warmly toward family, showing social awareness and control.
Responds sharply and annoyed when Blanche questions the house, indicating some impatience or defensiveness.
Confidently assures Maxwell about Mede's condition and ability to fight again after training.
Provides clear, practical instructions to Lucrezia Borgia for caring for Mede, including nutrition advice.
Takes an active role in assessing Mede's condition and readiness, showing attentiveness and decisiveness.
Takes Maxwell aside to discuss a sensitive family matter quietly, showing consideration to keep it from Ellen's hearing.
Buys Ellen as a 'bed wench' and shows a somewhat tender regard for her, despite the objectifying circumstances.
Is defensive and flustered when Maxwell comments on his tender regard for Ellen, indicating some emotional sincerity though limited by social norms.
Takes Maxwell aside to discuss a sensitive matter quietly and shares the document for examination.
Buys Ellen for a high price, showing confidence/finality in decision.
Defends his purchase to Maxwell, showing some assertiveness.
Seems unaware or naive about the social consequences of being tender about a wench, as pointed out by Maxwell and Blanche.
Flustered and reddened by his father's blunt observations about social norms and his actions.
Refuses to sleep in the room with Blanche, avoids discussing issues, ignores Blanche's anger and accusations, gazes venomously and uses sarcasm towards her
Sets a threatening tone when he tells Tense to leave the room and does not intervene when Blanche frightens the girl
Does not answer Blanche's questions about going to another woman, leaves the room without addressing conflict
Grabs and pitches Meg in the tub despite Meg's refusal to wash in Ellen's water; enforces obedience harshly.
Walks to Ellen and embraces her tenderly; caresses and compliments her beauty sincerely.
Laughs good-naturedly with Agamemnon despite minor contradiction.
States 'We treat them as they ought to be treated' in response to Blanche's criticism of his treatment of slaves.
Shows concern when Blanche expresses feeling neglected.
Teases Agamemnon by saying 'I'm a-likin' you less every day.'
Encourages Mede, urging him to do better and shows care by giving him cloth to prevent chills.
Throws a cloth to Mede to prevent chills before the fight, helps dry Mede's back himself, watches Mede with admiration.
Smiles approvingly as Mede chops down a tree, encouraging him.
Warns other slaves about punishment if they laugh at Mede.
Watches the fight between Mede and Vulcan, praises Mede's performance, and instructs for him to be rubbed down afterward.
Refers to Blanche as 'temperance like an old drunk' and scowls at her when she is upset
Reluctantly goes to follow Blanche after his father orders him to but stands unmoving at first
Enters room looking tired but happy and seems somewhat attentive to family dynamics
Encourages Mede to enter the hot brine despite his fear, showing concern by testing the water himself.
Doubtfully comments that the hot brine might soften Mede instead of toughening him, expressing worry or care.
Expresses doubt about the toughening effect of the hot brine and warns that it could soften Mede instead of toughening him.
Physically tests the hot brine himself by plunging his hand into the cauldron to assess the temperature.
Reassures Ellen he will not sell their young slave, promises to raise him right at Falconhurst.
Expresses anger and suspicion toward Ellen when she asks if the slave could be freed, harshly challenges her desire for freedom.
Softens after initial anger and promises Ellen the slave will be freed, embraces her.
Insists on keeping their own slave ('our sucker') to raise him at Falconhurst, showing a desire to control and manage the situation.
Reacts strongly and angrily when Ellen suggests the slave could be free, indicating emotional impulsiveness and rigidity.
Eventually promises Ellen that the slave will go free, showing some flexibility and ability to accommodate others' concerns.
Commands two women to forcibly remove Blanche from the path of the carriage, showing willingness to use violence on women to assert control.
Waves goodbye to Ellen as the carriage moves off, a small gesture of farewell.
Interacts with people at the Music Academy, receives affectionate gestures from women and responds with a 'wicked leer' and nostalgic sigh.
Whispers encouragement to Mede before the fight and places hand encouragingly on Mede's shoulder despite his concern.
Expresses anxiety and concern for Mede during the fight, showing emotional involvement.
Whispers encouragement to Mede and advises him to fight slow and wear out the opponent.
Watches the fight anxiously and appears astounded and heavy with concern, showing nervousness.
Expresses panic and doubt about Mede's chances against a seasoned opponent.
Looks stricken and clenches his hands watching the brutal fight, showing concern for Mede's plight.
Bounces up and down in his chair with excitement and enjoyment despite Mede being badly beaten, seemingly unconcerned about Mede's suffering.
Looks stricken with concern, hands clenched, appears overwhelmed by the fight's situation, not intervening or taking control.
Bounces up and down in his chair with excitement, seemingly unconcerned about the fight's outcome and unable to influence events positively.
Yields the fight and offers to pay the bets to stop further harm.
Encourages Mede to keep fighting and win despite the brutal battle.
Rushed to Mede after the fight, showing disbelief but recognizing the victory and its cost.
Celebrates a victory that involved a lethal outcome, potentially indicating poor ethical judgment or lack of foresight.
Refuses to sell Mede to fight again despite a $10,000 offer, shows pain and guilt looking at Mede's injuries, comforts Mede by putting his arm around him and leading him away.
Seems dejected and does not reprimand Mede for insulting the plantation's reputation, saying 'I guess I is.'
Does not speak up or assert himself in front of Maxwell regarding Mede's statement.
Receives ruby necklace and earrings from his father for his wife, contemplates responding but chooses silence.
Appears dejected and injured, shows little energy or confidence when Mede insults Falconhurst.
Passively allows Maxwell to reprimand Mede instead of addressing the insult himself.
Receives ruby jewelry from his father seemingly reluctantly, perhaps indicating uncertainty or hesitation.
Examines Ellen closely for injuries and devises a cover story to protect her from punishment.
Uses threats and manipulation to coerce Ellen into silence, showing skill in controlling situations and people under pressure.
Shows emotional support by embracing Ellen after hearing her story, demonstrating emotional intelligence alongside practical competence.
Brings a gift (earrings) to Blanche, causing her joy and admiration.
Shares a moment of gentle, sincere connection with Blanche after Maxwell locks them in.
Nods in response to Maxwell's expectations, brings a gift to Blanche, remains calm under Maxwell's authoritative and tense behavior.
Does not resist being locked in the room, appears passive and uncomfortable but does not assert himself or challenge the situation.
Responds warmly to Bianche's affectionate kiss and rush of feeling.
Engages in a friendly and humorous exchange with Mede, laughing at a joke about cotton.
Probes Mede about freedom in a thoughtful, gentle manner and shows satisfaction at Mede's comfort.
Engages in a thoughtful and probing conversation with Mede about freedom, showing curiosity and empathy.
Laughs off a potentially serious or challenging idea without fully addressing its implications (laughs at Mede’s comment about cotton).
Calmly assesses the weather and the fields, showing awareness of conditions affecting the plantation.
Accepts Mede’s satisfaction with his current status as free, showing some confidence in his understanding.
Nods satisfied and smiles, indicating confidence in his current position or plan.
Engages casually and commands in household setting, ensuring Mede receives the same meal, showing practical management.
Allows others to take moral or religious high ground argument without intervening or clarifying his own stance, demonstrating omission in leadership.
Chuckles at the idea that his new house will cost a lot of slaves, pleased by his own wealth and power.
Notices the problematic necklace on Ellen and shows anger, rising with a pained, foolish expression before following Blanche after she removes her earrings and leaves.
Tells Dite to take her baby and keep it, encouraging her to run off with the child despite Maxwell's objections.
Reassures Ellen that he is not going to sell her and urges her to come with him, noticing her fear and acting protectively.
Tells Dite to take her baby and leave quickly despite Maxwell's objections, showing decisiveness and protective instinct under pressure.

No direct action or statement in the excerpt to evaluate competence.
Believes Blanche's accusation without verification and is implied to be easily manipulated by her.

Responds quizzically but pleased to Blanche's attentiveness, indicating social awareness and confidence.

Sees Ellen doing laundry, and she turns away immediately, avoiding him.

Responds to Ellen's fear with comfort and sincerity, affirming her value and place despite the troubles.
Shows concern about Ellen's hysteria and the strange behavior of others, indicating caring and attentiveness.

Rides after Cicero to capture or aid him amid danger.

Races out of the room towards the dead infant after learning it is a boy, showing urgency but also emotional overwhelm.
Stands immobile and horrified upon seeing the dead black infant, evidently unable to control or process the situation calmly.
Descends stairs looking ghastly pale and with knees rubbery, physically weakened and affected by the situation.
Conveys the information that the 'poison powder' used to kill old slaves no longer works, implying awareness of changing conditions or problems in their system.

Shakes his head and leaves the room abruptly when Maxwell questions the story, indicating reluctance to engage or reconsider alternative perspectives.

Fails to elicit compliance from Mede, who defies him and threatens not to obey, showing that Hammond's authority and commands are not absolute or fully effective.
Fires rifle at Mede to stop him, then proceeds to brutally hold Mede underwater with a pitchfork until Mede dies; responds violently and calls Agamemnon a fool when intervening.
Steps toward Agamemnon, tells him to put down the gun, then rushes to his wounded father, kneels beside him and holds his hand with a look of grief and horror.
Takes a step toward Agamemnon, attempts to de-escalate the situation by telling him to put the gun down.
Rushed to his father's side after he was shot, showing concern but not intervening effectively to prevent the shooting.

Kisses his father in a farewell, indicating affection and respect.
Informs Dite that she should stay as a house servant and not tire herself because he has a new wench, dismissing her with little regard for her feelings.
Calls Ellen to come with him, putting her in a situation where she feels shame and is isolated from Dite.
Shows concern for Big Fearl by ordering Lucrezia to put packs on his bruised face to help him heal.
Capitulates (gives in) rather than asserting authority, indicating a possible lack of firm control.
Clearly delegates tasks properly by instructing Lucrezia and managing servants (e.g., telling Dite to stay and tend to household duties).
Fails to address or console Dite’s emotional pain directly despite being aware of it.
Reacts to Meg's refusal to wash by forcibly pitching him into the tub, asserting authority.
Walks to Ellen and tenderly embraces her, showing emotional confidence.
Expresses thoughtful observation about Ellen's beauty that contradicts social expectations, showing reflection and confidence.
Laughs at Agamemnon’s confident (but incorrect) assertion about the weather, showing social ease and confidence.
Treats his servants according to his own ideas of proper treatment, addresses disagreements firmly but avoids escalating quarrels too quickly.
Appears surprised and concerned when Blanche challenges his plans, revealing some unpreparedness for opposition or insight into family dynamics.
Behaves pettily and peevish when the heavy rain begins, blaming Agamemnon, which shows some lack of emotional control.
Gallops confidently on horseback, encourages Mede to perform better, prepares him carefully for the fight by attending to his health.
Responds with a chilly, unfeeling gaze to Blanche's vulnerable plea for intimacy and pulls his hand away, rejecting her and showing detachment.
Supervises Mede's treatment with ointment and comments lightly about the smell, showing a practical but somewhat detached involvement.
Uneasily admits the fighter could use more training, showing awareness of limitations.
Warns Blanche firmly about the inappropriate nature of her presence and the lack of room in the carriage, attempting to control the situation.
Reacts with unpleasant surprise to Blanche's drunken state and disruptive behavior, potentially showing emotional disturbance.
Encourages Mede during the fight with anguished eyes and voice, urging him to keep going and win.
Rushes to Mede after the fight's violent outcome, exclaiming 'We won! We killed him!'
Refuses to sell Mede to make him fight again; shows compassion and moral firmness in protecting Mede despite pressure.
Shows pain and guilt seeing Mede's battered condition, tries to help him physically by putting an arm around him and leading him off.
Angrily confronts Maxwell for wanting to sell Mede again, indicating emotional involvement but also a lack of detachment that could cloud judgment.
Accepts ruby necklace and earrings from his father but puts the boxes in his pocket without further interest, refrains from commenting despite seeming ready to speak.
Puts the boxes with ruby jewelry in his pocket without further interest despite his father's clear intention to please his wife.
Rocks Ellen tenderly in his arms to comfort her while she is crying.
Gives Ellen a ruby necklace from the city as a gift, trying to cheer her up.
Rocks Ellen tenderly to console her and gives her a thoughtful gift to cheer her up.
Displays affection toward Ellen confidently despite his father's displeasure.
Takes initiative to calm and support Ellen in a difficult moment.
Smiles and expresses satisfaction when Mede says he is happy, tells Mede he is free riding through the fields.
Enters the kitchen with Mede and ensures he is served the same food as the family.
Demonstrates financial confidence, knowing he can well afford the expensive house.
Actively participates in planning the sale of slaves, showing involvement in business matters.
Allows a social situation to escalate into personal conflict due to a poorly judged gift (the necklace to Ellen).
Appears foolish and pained after being confronted about the necklace incident, indicating emotional unpreparedness or poor social judgment.
Kisses his father again before leaving, showing affection.
Shouts the order for blacks to move off, showing authoritative control without noted kindness.
Kisses his father again, confidently gives orders to move everyone off despite emotional tension.
Displays confident leadership in directing a group under stressful circumstances.
Believes and supports Blanche's false accusation against Mede, leading to Mede's likely death.
Sniffs the air and detects something wrong, shows suspicion and attentiveness.
Appears confused and perplexed when questioning Lucrezia Borgia's denial of the smell.
Quickens his pace, eager to display the infant to his father, showing confidence and pride in his role.
Expresses a desire for many 'suckers' like the infant for breeding, indicating a focused and purposeful approach to his goals.
Laughs off Mede's refusal of money, indicating a casual and confident social interaction.
Is surprised by Blanche's civility and pleasant behavior, showing some degree of unpreparedness for unexpected social dynamics.
Hands the infant to Mede and instructs to take it back to Big Pearl, showing care for the baby's wellbeing.
Responds quizzically but pleased to Blanche's caring offer of whiskey, appreciating her solicitude.
Muses about the infant's monetary value and notes Mede's unpleasant smell, showing a commodifying and disdainful attitude.
Shakes and looks pale with concern when Mede is stricken; paces nervously near Blanche in labor; locks the door and goes upstairs to attend to her privacy and safety; listens to reassurances quietly
Shouts loudly into Beatrix’s ear trumpet and offers her a drink (which she refuses disdainfully)
Allows Beatrix to accuse him of being a beast but does not respond aggressively or defensively
Shakes and pales, paces nervously during the crisis around Blanche's labor.
Locks the door and goes upstairs to presumably safeguard the situation.
Attempts to maintain composure by joking about his rheumatism and offers a drink to Beatrix.
Races out of the room upon hearing bad news about the dead infant.
Stands horrified and immobile looking at the dead black baby, showing visible distress but no comforting action.
Appears haggard and ghastly pale, physically shaken by the situation.
Speaks numbingly about the ineffectiveness of the poison powder used on slaves, showing a resigned acknowledgment rather than empathy or consolation.
Gently administers medicine to Elanche and eases her back on pillows.
Wakes Mede abruptly, holding a gun and displaying relentlessness; his eyes glaze Mede with fear.
Commands Mede and Lucy to help with the cauldron and fire, watching them vigilantly with a rifle in hand.
Commands others clearly and takes charge of the situation, prepares a fire and cauldron efficiently while armed and vigilant.
Moves others with authority despite their fear, showing control and planning in a tense environment.

Maxwell.Action: Speaks warmly to Blanche, inviting her to sit by him and inquiring about her night with apparent concern.
